Translated by the Tang Dynasty Indian Åšramaá¹‡a PrajÃ±Ä (ParamÄrtha) Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
How are the six sense bases the wondrous true suchness nature of the TathÄgata's treasury?
Ä€nanda!

The essence of the eyes, when strained and exhausted, along with the eyes and exhaustion, are both the characteristics of the straining and exhaustion of bodhi. Due to the two deluded objects of light and darkness, seeing arises in the middle and absorbs these phenomenal images, which is called the nature of seeing. This seeing, apart from the two objects of light and darkness, ultimately has no substance.
Thus, Ä€nanda!
You should know that this seeing does not come from light and darkness, does not arise from the sense organ, and does not arise from empty space.
Why is this?
If it comes from light, then darkness would immediately cease, and it should not be able to see darkness.
If it came from darkness, then when the light came, the darkness would disappear and there would be no seeing of the light.
If it were produced from the sense organ, then it would necessarily be independent of light and darkness.
In this way, the essence of seeing is originally without self-nature.
If it emerged from space, then when facing the forms of objects, it would return to the seeing organ;
and moreover, space would be observing itself, what relation would it have to your sense organ?
Therefore, you should know that the sense organ of the eyes is false and unreal, originally neither causes and conditions nor natural.
Ä€nanda!

Suppose someone were to use their two fingers to quickly block their ears. Because the sense organ of hearing is strained, sounds are produced in the head. Moreover, the ears and the strain are both the same as bodhi.

The appearance of strained vision is caused by the two deluded sense objects of movement and stillness. The hearing that arises in between and absorbs these sense objects is called the nature of hearing. This hearing, apart from those two sense objects of movement and stillness, ultimately has no substance.
In this way, Ä€nanda!
You should know that this hearing does not come from movement and stillness, is not produced from the sense organ, and does not arise from space.
Why is this?

If it comes from stillness, then movement would immediately cease, and one would not hear movement.ğŸ”½If it comes from movement, then stillness would immediately cease, and one would not be aware of stillness.
If it arises from the sense organ, then there would definitely be no movement or stillness.
In this way, the essence of hearing is originally without self-nature.
If it emerges from space, then hearing would have a nature of its own and would not be empty space;
furthermore, if space itself heard, what would that have to do with your sense of hearing?
Therefore, you should know that the sense of hearing is false and originally neither causes and conditions, nor spontaneous.

Ä€nanda,ğŸ”½Suppose someone constricts their nose too tightly, and after a long time of constriction, they become fatigued. They will then smell a cold sensation in their nose. Based on that sensation, they discriminate between unobstructed and obstructed, empty and real, and even various fragrant and foul odors, along with the nose and fatigue, are all bodhi.

The appearance of staring and fatigue arises from the two false objects of unobstructed and obstructed. The hearing that occurs in the middle, which sucks in the images of these objects, is called the nature of smelling and hearing. This hearing, apart from the two objects of unobstructed and obstructed, ultimately has no substance.
You should know that this hearing does not come from the open or blocked, it does not emerge from the faculties, and it is not born from empty space.
Why is this?
If it came from the open, the blocked would naturally disappear. How could it know the blocked?
If it exists due to the blocked, then there would be no hearing when there is openness. How could it discern smells, scents, and other sensations?
If it were born from the faculties, it would necessarily be without openness or blockage.
In this way, the essence of hearing is originally without self-nature.
If it came from empty space, this hearing would naturally turn to smell your nose. The space itself would have hearing. How would it be related to your faculties?
Therefore, you should know that the faculty of the nose is false and unreal. It is originally neither due to causes and conditions, nor does it arise spontaneously.
Ä€nanda!

Suppose someone uses their tongue to lick their lips, licking them until they are tired. If that person is sick, there will be a bitter taste. A healthy person will have a slight sweet sensation. Due to the sweet and bitter, this tongue faculty becomes apparent. When it is not moving, the neutral taste is always present.

The tongue and the labor are both the same in being the appearances of the development of labor in the eyes. Due to the two deluded objects of sweetness, bitterness, and blandness, the consciousness arises in between and sucks in the images of these objects, which is called the nature of the consciousness of taste. This nature of the consciousness of taste, apart from the two objects of sweetness, bitterness, and blandness, ultimately has no substance.
Thus, Ä€nanda!

You should know that this consciousness of tasting bitterness and blandness does not come from sweetness and bitterness, is not due to blandness, does not arise from the tongue, and does not arise from empty space.
Why is this?ğŸ”½If it comes from sweetness and bitterness, then when encountering blandness, the consciousness of sweetness and bitterness would cease. How could it know blandness?
If it arises from blandness, then when encountering sweetness and bitterness, the consciousness of blandness would be lost. How could it know the two characteristics of sweetness and bitterness?
If it arises from the tongue itself, then it would definitely not have the objects of sweetness, blandness, and bitterness.
This consciousness of taste would have no inherent nature of its own.

If it arises from empty space, then empty space itself would have a taste that is not known by your mouth. Moreover, if empty space itself were conscious, how would it be related to your sense of taste?
Therefore, you should know that the sense-field of the tongue is false and unreal, not arising from causes and conditions, and not arising spontaneously.
Ä€nanda!

Suppose someone uses a cold hand to touch a hot hand. If the power of cold is greater, the hot one becomes cold; if the power of heat is superior, the cold one becomes hot. In this way, the awareness of contact through union manifests the knowledge of separation. If the power of contact through exertion is established, it is due to the effort of contact.

Together with the body and effort, both are the characteristics of the deluded appearances arising from the enlightenment. Due to the two false objects of separation and union, the awareness arises in between and absorbs these phenomenal images, called the nature of awareness.
The essence of this awareness, apart from the two objects of separation, union, opposition, and compliance, ultimately has no substance.
Thus, Ä€nanda!

You should know that this awareness does not come from separation and union, does not exist due to opposition and compliance, does not arise from the sense faculties, and does not arise from emptiness.
Why is it so?
If it comes when united, it should have ceased when separated. How can it be aware of separation?
The two aspects of opposition and compliance are also like this.
If it comes from the faculties, it must be without the four aspects of separation, union, opposition, and compliance.
Then the knowing of your body originally has no self-nature.
If it comes from space, space itself would know and perceive, how is it related to your faculty of body?
Therefore, you should know that the faculty of body is false and originally neither due to causes and conditions, nor spontaneous.
Ä€nanda!

It is like a person who is tired and sleeps, and upon waking up, recollects the perceived objects. Losing recollection is delusion, which is the arising, abiding, changing, and ceasing of the inverted [mind]. Absorbing and habituating in the middle, without exceeding [the present], is called the faculty of mental cognition.

Together with the mind and exertion, both are the characteristics of the deluded appearance of bodhi. Due to the two deluded objects of arising and ceasing, the cognition gathers in the middle and absorbs the internal objects. Seeing and hearing flow against the current, and the place where the current does not reach is called the nature of cognitive awareness.
This nature of cognitive awareness, apart from the two objects of arising and ceasing of waking and sleeping, ultimately has no substance.
Thus, Ä€nanda!
You should know that this faculty of cognition does not come from waking or sleeping, does not exist due to birth or cessation, does not emerge from the faculties, and is not born from emptiness.
Why is this?
If it comes from waking, then it would cease to exist when sleeping, so what would be the basis for sleep?
If it exists due to birth, then when it ceases it would be the same as nonexistence, so who would experience cessation?
If it exists due to cessation, then when birth occurs cessation would be nonexistent, so who would know the one who is born?

If it emerges from the faculties, then the two aspects of waking and sleeping would follow the opening and closing of the body. Apart from these two aspects, this aware cognition would be the same as empty flowers, ultimately without any nature.
If it is born from emptiness, then it would be emptiness itself that is aware. How does it relate to your faculty of cognition?
Therefore, you should know that the faculty of cognition is false and originally neither due to causes and conditions nor due to natural origination.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
How is it that the twelve sense fields are the wondrous true nature of the TathÄgatagarbha?
Ä€nanda!
You should observe this Jeta Grove and the springs and ponds.
What do you think? Do these arise from the eye seeing form?
Do the eyes give rise to the characteristics of form?
Ä€nanda!

If the eye faculty gives rise to the characteristics of form, then seeing empty space that is not form should cause the nature of form to be extinguished. If extinguished, then all would be nonexistent. Since the characteristics of form do not exist, what illuminates the substance of empty space?
Empty space is also like this.

If the sense object of form gives rise to the seeing of the eye, then observing empty space that is not form causes the seeing to be extinguished and destroyed. If destroyed, then all would be nonexistent. Who illuminates empty space and form?
Therefore, you should know that seeing and form and empty space have no location. The two places of form and seeing are both false and originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous.
Ä€nanda!
Listen again to the sound of the drum beaten to announce the meal and the bell rung to assemble the assembly in this Jeta Grove. The sounds of the drum and bell continue one after another.
What do you think? Do these sounds come to the side of the ear,
or does the ear go to the place of the sound?
Ä€nanda!
If this sound comes to the side of the ear, like when I beg for alms in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«, then there is no me in the Jeta Grove;

this sound must come to Ä€nanda's ears, and MaudgalyÄyana and KÄÅ›yapa should not hear it together, let alone the twelve hundred and fifty monks who all come to the meal together upon hearing the bell.
If your ear goes to the side of that sound, like when I return to stay in the Jeta Grove, then there is no me in the city of ÅšrÄvastÄ«;

when you hear the sound of the drum, your ear has already gone to where the drum is struck, and the sound of the bell should not be heard together, let alone the various sounds of elephants, horses, cows, sheep, and so forth.
If there is no coming and going, then there is also no hearing.
Therefore, you should know that hearing and sound have no location. The two places of hearing and sound are both false and originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous natures.
Ä€nanda!
You also smell this sandalwood in the censer. If only a single ounce of this incense is burned, the fragrance will be simultaneously smelled within forty miles of ÅšrÄvastÄ«.
What do you think? Does this fragrance arise from the sandalwood wood?
Does it arise from your nose?
Or does it arise from empty space?
Ä€nanda!
If this fragrance arises from your nose, then it should be produced by the nose and emerge from the nose. The nose is not sandalwood, so how can there be the scent of sandalwood within the nose?
If you say you smell the fragrance, then it should enter the nose. The fragrance emerging from the nose is not the meaning of smelling.
If it arises from empty space, the nature of empty space is always constant, so the fragrance should always be present. Why rely on burning this dry wood in the censer?

If it arises from the wood, then this fragrant substance is burned to form smoke. If the nose can smell it, it should only smell the smoke. The smoke rises into the air and has not yet reached far, so why is it already smelled within forty miles?

Therefore, you should know that smell, nose, and the act of smelling all have no location. The two locations of smelling and smell are both false and originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous natures.
Ä€nanda,
you always carry the alms bowl in the assembly during the two meals. Sometimes you encounter ghee, milk, and butter, which are considered the best flavors.
What do you think? Do these flavors arise in space,
arise from the tongue,
or arise in the food?
Ä€nanda,

if these flavors arise from your tongue, in your mouth there is only one tongue. When the tongue has already become the flavor of ghee, encountering black rock candy should not cause it to change. If it does not change, it cannot be called knowing the flavor. If it changes, the tongue is not of multiple bodies. How can many flavors be known by one tongue?
If they arise from the food, the food does not have consciousness. How can it know itself?
Moreover, if the food knows itself, it would be the same as the other food. How is it related to you, the one who knows the flavor?
If it arises from emptiness, what taste will you experience when you eat emptiness?
If emptiness has a salty taste, then since your tongue is salty, your face will also be salty, and then the people of this world will be the same as the fish in the sea;

since they will always experience saltiness, they will not know what blandness is. If they do not know blandness, they will not experience saltiness either. If they know nothing, how can it be called taste?
Therefore, you should know that taste and tongue and tasting all have no location. Tasting and taste are both illusory, and are originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous natures.
Ä€nanda!
You always touch your head with your hand in the morning.
What do you think? This knowledge of touching only serves to touch.
Does it exist in the hand?
Or does it exist in the head?ğŸ”½If it exists in the hand, the head will have no knowledge. How can it be called touching?
If it exists in the head, the hand will have no use. How can it be called touching?
If each has it, then you, Ä€nanda, should have two bodies.
If the head and hand were produced by a single contact, then the hand and head would be a single entity. If they were a single entity, contact would not be established.
If they were two entities, which contact would be present?
If present in the able, not in the receptive; if present in the receptive, not in the able.
It should not be that empty space becomes contact for you.
Therefore, you should know that the perception of contact and the body have no location. The body and contact are both false, originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous nature.
Ä€nanda!
The three natures of good, evil, and neutral that your mind always takes as objects to generate rules and methods,
are these rules and methods produced by the mind itself?
Or do they exist somewhere apart from the mind?
Ä€nanda!
If they are the mind, then the rules and methods are not objects and are not what the mind takes as objects. How can they be established as a location?
If they exist somewhere apart from the mind, then the intrinsic nature of the rules and methods would be either cognizable
or not cognizable.
If it is known, it is called mind. Different from you, it is not an object. The same as other minds, it is you and also mind. How can your mind be two for you?
If it is not known, this object is neither form, sound, smell, taste, touch, or temperature, nor the characteristic of empty space. Where should it exist?
Now, in form and emptiness there is no indication at all. It should not be that there is space outside the human world. The mind is not the object. From what is its location established?
Therefore, you should know that the dharma and the mind both have no location. Then, the mind and the dharma are both false, originally neither causes and conditions, nor spontaneous nature.
Furthermore, Ä€nanda!
How are the eighteen realms the wondrous true nature of the TathÄgatagarbha?
Ä€nanda!
As you have explained, eyes and forms as conditions give rise to the eye consciousness. Does this consciousness arise from the eye, with the eye as its realm?
Or does it arise from forms, with forms as its realm?
Ä€nanda!
If it arises from the eye, since there is no form or space to be discriminated, even if your consciousness exists, what would it be used for?
Your seeing is neither blue, yellow, red, or white, and has no indication. From what is the boundary established?
If it arises from form, when there is no form in space, your consciousness should cease. How can consciousness know the nature of empty space?
When form changes, you also cognize the transformation of the form's characteristics. If your consciousness does not change, from what is the boundary established?
If it changes along with [form], the characteristics of the boundary would be nonexistent.
If it does not change, it would be eternal.
Since it arises from form, it should not be able to cognize the location of empty space.

If it arises together from both the eye and form, if they are combined, the middle would be separated; if separated, the two would combine. The essence would be mixed up. How could it form a boundary?

Therefore, you should know that the eye and form as conditions give rise to the eye-consciousness boundary. The three locations are all nonexistent. Then the eye, form, and the form boundary, the three, are originally neither causes and conditions, nor spontaneous.
Moreover, what you have clarified, the ear and sound as conditions give rise to the ear consciousness.
Does this consciousness arise due to the ear, taking the ear as its boundary?
Or does it arise due to sound, taking sound as its boundary?
Ä€nanda,
if it arises due to the ear, when the two aspects of movement and stillness are not present, the faculty cannot be aware and must be unaware of anything;
since awareness is not yet formed, what is the appearance of consciousness?
If it takes the ear to hear, because there is no movement or stillness, hearing is not accomplished.
How can the shape of the ear, with its various colors and textures, be called the realm of consciousness? Then from what is the realm of ear consciousness established?
If it arises from sound, consciousness exists due to sound, then it is not related to hearing. Without hearing, the characteristics of sound are lost.

If consciousness arises from sound, it is accepted that sound has the characteristics of sound due to hearing. Hearing should hear consciousness. If it does not hear, it is not a boundary. If it hears, it is the same as sound. Consciousness has already been heard. Who knows the consciousness that hears? If there is no knower, it is ultimately like grass and trees.
The two vehicles should not be mixed in the middle realm. Since there is no middle position in the realm, then from what are the internal and external characteristics formed?

Therefore, you should know that the ear and sound are the conditions for the arising of the ear consciousness realm. Since the three locations do not exist, then the ear, sound, and sound realm are originally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous.
Ä€nanda!
Moreover, what you understand is that nose and smell are the conditions for the arising of the nose consciousness.
Does this consciousness arise from the nose, taking the nose as its boundary?
Or does it arise from smell, taking smell as its boundary?
Ä€nanda!
If it arises from the nose, then what do you take as the nose in your mind?
Do you take the appearance of the two claws of the flesh?
Or do you take the nature of the moving and shaking of the sense of smell?

If you take the flesh, the flesh is the body, and the body's awareness is touch. It is called the body, not the nose. It is called the dust, and the nose is still without a name. How can you establish a boundary?
If you take the sense of smell, then what do you take as the awareness in your mind?
If the nose consciousness were based on the flesh, then the essence of the flesh's consciousness would be contact, not the nose.

If the nose consciousness were based on space, then space would be self-aware and the flesh should not be aware. In that case, space would be you, and your body would not be aware. Then today, Ä€nanda, would not exist.
If the nose consciousness were based on smells, then awareness would belong to smells, what would that have to do with you?

If the smells of fragrance and stench necessarily arise from your nose, then the two kinds of flowing smells would not arise from the sandalwood or the frankincense tree. If the two objects do not come, you yourself smell your nose, is it fragrant or foul-smelling?

If it is foul-smelling, it cannot be fragrant, and if it is fragrant, it cannot be foul-smelling. If you can smell both fragrance and foul smells, then you, one person, should have two noses. When I ask about the Way, there are two Ä€nandas. Which one is your body?
If the nose is one, and fragrance and foul smell are not two, then foul smell becomes fragrance and fragrance becomes foul smell. If the two natures do not exist, from what is the realm established?

If the consciousness arises from fragrance, then it would exist because of fragrance. Just as the eye has seeing but cannot see the eye itself, because it exists because of fragrance, it should not be able to perceive fragrance. If it perceives, then it does not arise. If it does not perceive, then it is not consciousness.
Fragrance does not exist because of perception. The realm of fragrance is not established.

Consciousness does not perceive fragrance. The realm that is the cause is not established from fragrance. Since there is no middle, the inner and outer are not established. The nature of hearing is ultimately false.

Therefore, you should know that the nose and fragrance as conditions give rise to the nose consciousness realm. The three locations are all nonexistent. Then the nose, fragrance, and fragrance realmâ€”the threeâ€”are fundamentally neither causes and conditions nor spontaneous.
If it arises from the tongue, then all the sweet potatoes, plums, yellow myrobalan, salt, ginger, cinnamon, and so forth in the world would have no taste.
You yourself taste the tongue, is it sweet or bitter?
If the nature of the tongue is bitter, who comes to taste the tongue?
The tongue does not taste itself, who knows the sensation?
The nature of the tongue is not bitter, taste does not arise by itself, how can you establish a realm?
If it arises from taste, the consciousness itself is taste, it should be like the tongue faculty and not be able to taste itself, how can the consciousness know what is taste and what is not taste?

Moreover, all tastes do not arise from a single thing, since tastes arise from many things, the consciousness should have many substances. If the substance of the consciousness is one, the substance must arise from taste.

Salty, bland, sweet, and spicy, combined and co-arisen, all the various changes are the same as a single taste, there should be no distinction. Since there is no distinction, it cannot be called consciousness, how can it be called the tongue, taste, and consciousness realm?
It should not arise from empty space in your mind-consciousness.
The combination of tongue and taste is originally without self-nature in the middle. How can the element arise?
Therefore, you should know that the tongue, taste, and the tongue consciousness arise from the combination of the three, but the three are originally neither causes and conditions nor natural.
Ä€nanda!
You have also explained that the body and touch are the conditions that give rise to the body consciousness.
Does this consciousness arise from the body and take the body as its boundary?
Or does it arise from touch and take touch as its boundary?
Ä€nanda!
If it arises from the body, there must be no awareness of union or separation. What does the body perceive?
If it arises from touch, there must be no you. Who, apart from the body, knows union and separation?
Ä€nanda!ğŸ”½Objects do not touch the body, the body knows there is touch;
knowing the body is touch, knowing touch is the body.

The contact is not the body, and the body is not the contact. The two characteristics of body and contact have no location. If combined with the body, it becomes the intrinsic nature of the body itself. If separated from the body, it is the characteristics of empty space, etc. The internal and external are not established. How can the middle be established?
If the middle is not established, the nature of the internal and external is empty. From what is your consciousness produced? On what is the realm established?

Therefore, you should know that the realm of body consciousness arises from the conditions of body and contact. In the three locations, there is nothing at all. The body, contact, and the body realm, these three, are originally neither causes and conditions, nor spontaneous nature.
Ä€nanda!
Moreover, what you have clarified is that intention and dharmas as conditions give rise to mental consciousness.
Does this consciousness arise due to the mind, taking the mind as its realm?
Or does it arise due to dharmas, taking dharmas as its realm?
Ä€nanda!
If it arises due to the mind, there must be something contemplated in your mind, manifesting your mind.
If there is no prior dharma, the mind has nothing to arise from. Apart from conditions, there is no form. What use is there for consciousness?
Moreover, is your perceiving mind and the thinking and discerning nature the same or different?
If the same, it is the mind itself. How can it be born?
If different, it is not the same as the mind and should not be able to perceive.
If it cannot perceive, how can it be born from the mind?
If it can perceive, how can it be the mind?
Only sameness and difference have no established nature. How can the realm be established?
If it arises from dharmas, worldly dharmas are not apart from the five sense objects.
You observe the characteristics of form dharmas, sound dharmas, smell dharmas, taste dharmas, and touch dharmas, which are distinct and correspond to the five sense organs, not included in the mind.
Your consciousness definitely arises based on dharmas. Now carefully observe what the characteristics of dharmas are.
If apart from form, space, movement, stillness, openness, obstruction, combination, separation, arising, and ceasing, ultimately nothing can be obtained beyond these characteristics.

When arising, form, emptiness, and all dharmas arise together. When ceasing, form, emptiness, and all dharmas cease together. Since the cause does not exist, how can consciousness arise from it and take on a form?
Since the form does not exist, how can the realm arise?

Therefore, you should know that the mental faculty and dharmas are the conditions for the arising of the mental consciousness, and the three places are all nonexistent. Then the mental faculty, dharmas, and the mental consciousness realm are originally neither caused by conditions nor naturally arisen.
Ä€nanda addressed the Buddha, saying:
World-Honored One!
The TathÄgata has always said that the various transformations in the world are all due to the manifestation of the combination of the four great elements.
How is it that the TathÄgata rejects both causes and conditions and spontaneity?

I do not yet understand the meaning of this. I only pray that you will have compassion and reveal to sentient beings the definitive meaning of the Middle Way, the Dharma free from conceptual proliferation.
At that time, the World-Honored One told Ä€nanda:

You previously became disgusted with the teachings of the Å›rÄvakas and pratyekabuddhas, the lesser vehicles, and aroused the aspiration to diligently seek supreme enlightenment. Therefore, I have now revealed the ultimate truth to you.
How can you again entangle yourself in the frivolous arguments and conceptual causes and conditions of the world?

Although you have heard much, you are like a person who talks about medicine but cannot distinguish real medicine when it is right in front of them. The TathÄgata says that such a person is truly pitiable.
Now listen carefully, and I will analyze and reveal it for you, and also enable those who cultivate the Great Vehicle in the future to penetrate the true reality.
Ä€nanda remained silent, receiving the Buddha's holy intention.
Ä€nanda!
As you have said, the four great elements combine to give rise to the various transformations in the world.
Ä€nanda!
If the nature of those great elements is not a combination, then they cannot mix and combine with the other great elements, just as space does not combine with forms;

If they were to combine, they would be the same as a transformation, with beginning and end mutually accomplishing, birth and cessation continuing, birth and death, death and birth, like a whirling fire wheel with no rest.
Ä€nanda!
It is like water becoming ice and ice returning to water.

Consider the nature of earth: the coarse is the great earth, the fine is the subtle dust, down to the neighboring void dust, which is composed of seven parts of the extreme subtle form characteristics. Further analyzing the neighboring void, it is the true nature of emptiness.
Ä€nanda!
If this neighboring void is analyzed into empty space, you should know that empty space gives rise to form characteristics.
You now ask:
Because of combination, the various transformation characteristics of the world are born.
You should consider this one neighboring void dust: how many empty spaces combine to exist?
It should not be that neighboring voids combine to form neighboring voids.
Moreover, when neighboring void dust is analyzed and enters emptiness, how many form characteristics are used to combine into empty space?
When form combines, the combination is form, not emptiness;
When empty space comes together, the coming together of space is not form.
Form can still be analyzed, but how can space come together?
You have never known that within the TathÄgata's treasury, the nature of form is true emptiness, and the nature of emptiness is true form, pure, originally thus, and pervading the Dharma realm;
In accordance with the minds of sentient beings, manifesting in response to their knowledge and understanding.

The ignorant in the world are confused by causes and conditions and the nature of spontaneity, all of which are distinctions and calculations of the discriminating mind. There are only words, but no true meaning.
Ä€nanda!
The nature of fire has no self and relies on various conditions.
When a family in the city has not yet eaten and wishes to cook, they hold a sun-catching mirror in front of the sun to seek fire.
Ä€nanda!

As for the term 'combination', it is like myself and you, together with the 1,250 bhiká¹£us, now forming a single assembly. Although the assembly is one, if we examine its basis, each has a body, and all have clans and personal names from their places of birth. For example, ÅšÄriputra is of the brÄhmaá¹‡a caste, UruvilvÄ-KÄÅ›yapa is of the á¹›á¹£i caste, and so on, up to Ä€nanda who is of the Gautama clan.
Ä€nanda!
If this fire nature exists due to a combination, when one holds a mirror in the sun to seek fire, does this fire come out of the mirror?ğŸ”½Does it come out of the tinder?
Or does it come from the sun?
Ä€nanda!
If it comes from the sun, it should be able to burn the tinder in your hand by itself, and the forests and trees along the way should all be set ablaze.
If it comes out of the mirror, it should be able to come out of the mirror and burn the tinder. Why doesn't the mirror melt?
Even though you hold it in your hand, there is no sign of heat. How could it melt?
If it arises from the cotton, why does it depend on the sun, mirror, and the connection of light before fire can arise?
Moreover, carefully observe that the mirror is held in the hand, the sun comes from the sky, and the cotton grows from the ground. From which direction does the fire travel here?
The sun and mirror are far apart, not combined or mixed. It should not be that the firelight exists without a source.
You still do not know that within the TathÄgatagarbha, the nature of fire is the true void, and the nature of void is the true fire, pure, originally thus, and pervades the Dharma realm;
